tit.e: The History of Japan Railways (the Meiji Period)

sen.j: 日本の鉄道史（明治）では、幕末から明治が終わるまでの期間の日本の鉄道の変遷について概説する。
sen.e: The history of Japan railways (the Meiji Period) covers the summary of the changes that took place from the end of the Edo Period to the end of the Meiji Period.
The history of Japanese railways (the Meiji Period) covers the summary of the changes that took place from the end of the Edo Period to the end of the Meiji Period.
The history of Japanese railways (the Meiji Period) covers the summary of the changes that took place from the end of the Edo Period to the end of the Meiji Period.

sen.j: この期間はイギリス等の先進国から、蒸気機関車が牽引する列車による鉄道経営が導入され、それらの技術やノウハウが国産化して確立され、鉄道網が日本全国に広がった。
sen.e: During this period, business operation of railways that ran steam powered locomotive to pull trains was introduced from England and other advanced countries, the technology and know-how of these countries were used for domestic production that led to the spread of networked railroads throughout Japan.

During this period, along with the steam powered locomotive that was introduced from England and other advanced countries, the technology and know-how of these countries were used for domestic production, which led to the spread of networked railroads throughout Japan.

sen.e: During this period, along with the steam powered locomotive that was introduced from England and other advanced countries, the technology and know-how of these countries were used for domestic production, which led to the spread of networked railroads throughout Japan.

sen.j: この間鉄道は「物珍しい先進国の技術」から始まって、旅行の足、産業発展に不可欠な輸送機関、戦争遂行のための道具などの責務を担った。
sen.e: Around this time, what began as a "curious technology from an advanced country" moved on to serve as a means of travel, an indispensable means of transportation for industrial development, and a tool for war and other functions.

Around this time, what began as a "curious technology from an advanced country" moved on to serve as a means of travel, an indispensable means of transportation for industrial development, and a tool for war and other functions.

tit.j: 日本人と鉄道との出会い
tit.e: The introduction of railways to the Japanese people.

sen.j: 1825年、蒸気機関を利用する鉄道が初めてイギリスで実用化された。
sen.e: In 1825, the railway that used steam engine was put in operational service the first time in England.
In 1825, the railway that used steam engine was put in operational service the first time in England.

sen.j: この技術は約30年後、幕末（1853年）の日本に蒸気車の模型として到来した。
sen.e: This technology was brought to Japan 30 years later during Bakumatsu (1853) as a steam engine model.
This technology was brought to Japan 30 years later at the end of the Edo period (1853) as a steam engine model.

tit.j: イギリスでの鉄道発祥

sen.j: 世界で最初の蒸気鉄道は、イギリスの炭鉱で産出した石炭を運搬する目的でストックトンとダーリントン間約40kmに設営されたものである。
sen.e: The world's first steam engine railroad was built between Stockton and Darlington for the approximate distance of 40km for the purpose of tranporting coal produced in England mines.
The world's first steam locomotive railroad was built to move coal that was produced in an English mine between Stockton and Darlington about the distance of 40km.
sen.cmt: 蒸気鉄道の一部訳漏れを補充します。procured→produced, England mine→English mine,石炭の関係代名詞を直後に移動します。
sen.e: The world's first steam locomotive railroad was built to move coal that was produced in an English mine between Stockton and Darlington about the distance of 40km.

sen.j: 機関車としてジョージ・スチーブンソンが設計したロコモーション号が使用された。
sen.e: The idea of "locomotion" designed by George Stevenson was used for the locomotive.
The "Locomotion" designed by George Stevenson was used for the locomotive.
sen.cmt: ロコモーション号の誤訳を訂正。
sen.e: The "Locomotion" designed by George Stevenson was used for the locomotive.

sen.j: この鉄道は石炭輸送を主目的としており、旅客の依頼があれば鉄道上を馬に牽引された車輌で利用することができた。
sen.e: The main use of this railroad was for transporting coal and it could also be used to carry passengers in horse carriage if requested.
The main use of this railroad was transporting coal and it could also be used to carry passengers in horse carriage if requested.
The main use of this railroad was transporting coal and it could also be used to carry passengers in horse carriage if requested.

sen.j: ちなみにここで採用された軌間4フィート8インチが、国際標準軌間の4フィート8インチ1/2 (1435mm) の基本になったとされる。
sen.e: Incidentally, the track gauge, the track gauge of 4 feet and 8 inches (1435mm) adopted here became a basis for the international standard track gauge of 4 feet and 8 and a half inches.
Speaking about the track gauge, the international standard track gauge 4' 8 and a half inches (1435mm) was based on the track gauge used here.

sen.j: 本格的な客貨両用鉄道は1830年にイギリスで開通したリバプール・アンド・マンチェスター鉄道で蒸気機関車ロケット号を使用した。
sen.e: Full service passenger and cargo railroad service by Liverpool and Manchester Railway came on line in 1830 in England pulled by a locomotive "Rocket".
Full service passenger and cargo railroad service by Liverpool and Manchester Railway came on line in 1830 in England pulled by a locomotive "Rocket".

sen.j: その後鉄道は先進各国で産業発展の担い手として発達して行った。
sen.e: From that time on, railways were making progress in advanced countries as a bearer of industrial development.
From that time on, railways made progress in advanced countries as a bearer of industrial development.

tit.e: The introduction of the model railway.

sen.j: 日本で初めて走った鉄道は、艦船に積んで運ばれてきた模型であった。
sen.e: The first railway ran in Japan was a model railway brought over in a military ship.
The first railway train in Japan was a model railway train brought over in a military ship.
sen.cmt: 「日本で初めて走った鉄道は、」の誤りを訂正します。railway→railway train
sen.e: The first railway train in Japan was a model railway train brought over in a military ship.

sen.j: 幕末の嘉永6年（1853年）7月、ロシアのエフィム・プチャーチンが率いる4隻の軍艦が長崎に入港して江戸幕府と開国の交渉を行った。
sen.e: In July 1853, four Russian warships commanded by Evfimiy Vasil'evich Putyatin sailed into Nagasaki harbor and the Russians negotiated an opening of the country to the world with Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

In July 1853, four Russian warships commanded by Evfimiy Vasil'evich Putyatin sailed into Nagasaki harbor and he negotiated the opening of the country to the world with Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

In July 1853, four Russian warships commanded by Evfimiy Vasil'evich Putyatin sailed into Nagasaki harbor and he negotiated the opening of the country to the world with Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 約半年に及ぶ滞在期間中に何人かの日本人を艦上に招待して、蒸気車の模型の運転を展示した。
sen.e: During their stay of almost over a half year, they invited a few Japanese guests on board to demonstrate a model steam locomotive in operation.
During his stay of almost over a half year, he invited a few Japanese guests on board to demonstrate a model steam locomotive in operation.
During his stay of almost over a half year, he invited a few Japanese guests on board to demonstrate a model steam locomotive in operation.

sen.j: 招待されたのは幕府の川路左衛門尉、佐賀県鍋島藩の本島藤夫、同じく飯島奇輔らであった。
sen.e: Their invited Japanese guests were Saemon no jo KAWAJI from Bakufu, Fujio MOTOJIMA and Kitasuku IIJIMA from Saga Nabeshima Domain and others.
The invited Japanese guests were Saemon no jo KAWAJI from Bakufu, Fujio MOTOJIMA and Kitasuku IIJIMA from Saga Nabeshima Domain and others.
The invited Japanese guests were Saemon no jo KAWAJI from Bakufu, Fujio MOTOJIMA and Kitasuku IIJIMA from Saga Nabeshima Domain and others.

sen.j: 佐賀藩士等は藩に戻って藩主に報告したが、この2年後の安政2年（1855年）2月、佐賀藩は蒸気機関車の模型を完成させた。
sen.e: The feudal retainers of the Saga clan reported it to their Lord upon their return to their domain, and two years thereafter in February of the second year of Ansei era (1855), Saga clan completed a model steam locomotive.
The feudal retainers of the Saga clan reported it to their Lord upon return and in February, 1855, two years thereafter, Saga clan completed a model steam locomotive.
sen.cmt: retainersと複数にします。訳漏れ「安政2年（1855年）2月、」追加します。
sen.e: The feudal retainers of the Saga clan reported it to their Lord upon return and in February, 1855, two years thereafter, Saga clan completed a model steam locomotive.

sen.j: 長崎に続いて1854年横浜で蒸気車の模型が走ったが、この時は模型といえども日本人（幕臣河田八之助）が客車の屋根にまたがって乗車した。
sen.e: Following Nagasaki, a model steam engine locomotive ran in Yokohama in 1854, and although it was just a model, it carried a passenger (bakushin shogun's retainer) Yanosuke KAWADA) who rode on it.

Following Nagasaki, a model steam engine locomotive ran in Yokohama in 1854, and although it was just a model, it carried a passenger (bakushin shogun's retainer, Yanosuke KAWADA) who rode over the roof.

sen.e: Following Nagasaki, a model steam engine locomotive ran in Yokohama in 1854, and although it was just a model, it carried a passenger (bakushin shogun's retainer, Yanosuke KAWADA) who rode over the roof.

sen.j: この模型はアメリカ合衆国のマシュー・ペリー提督が2回目の日本訪問に際して大統領から将軍への献上品として持参したものであった。
sen.e: This model was presented to the Shogun as a gift from the President of the United States of America on the second visit to Japan by Commodore Matthew Perry.
This model was presented to the Shogun as a gift from the President of the United States of America by Commodore Matthew Perry on his second visit to Japan.
sen.cmt: on the second visit to Japan by Commodore Matthew Perry.→ by Commodore Matthew Perry on his second visit to Japan.
sen.e: This model was presented to the Shogun as a gift from the President of the United States of America by Commodore Matthew Perry on his second visit to Japan.

sen.j: 明治維新の翌年、政府は官営による鉄道建設を決定し、新橋・横浜間の鉄道建設が始まった。
sen.e: In the following year of the Meiji restoration, the government decided to construct the government-owned railways and the construction of the railroad between Shinbashi and Yokohama was started.
In the following year of the Meiji restoration, the construction of the national railroad between Shinbashi and Yokohama was started.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ「政府は官営による鉄道建設を決定し、」
sen.e: In the following year of the Meiji restoration, the government decided to construct the government-owned railways and the construction of the railroad between Shinbashi and Yokohama was started.

sen.j: 京都で王政復古の大号令が布告された半月後の慶応3年（1867年）6月、幕府の老中外国事務総裁小笠原長行の名でアメリカ領事館書記官のアルセ・ポートマン宛に江戸・横浜市間の鉄道設営免許が与えられた。
sen.e: A half month after the Decree for the Restoration of Imperial Rule in June 1867, a construction license for the railroad between Edo and Yokohama City was issued to American consulate secretary Aluse Portman signed by Nagayuki OGASAWARA, a bakufu roju (member of shogun's council of elders) who was the head of the foreign affairs.

A half month after the Decree for the Restoration of Imperial Rule in June 1867, a construction license for the railroad between Edo and Yokohama City was issued to American consulate secretary Aluse Portman signed by Nagayuki OGASAWARA, a bakufu roju (member of shogun's council of elders) and Gaikoku Jimu Sosai.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ「外国事務総裁」追加します。
sen.e: A half month after the Decree for the Restoration of Imperial Rule in June 1867, a construction license for the railroad between Edo and Yokohama City was issued to American consulate secretary Aluse Portman signed by Nagayuki OGASAWARA, a bakufu roju (member of shogun's council of elders) and Gaikoku Jimu Sosai.

sen.j: この免許はアメリカ側に経営権がある「外国管轄方式」といえるものであった。
sen.e: This license was structured under the "foreign jurisdiction method" where the management rights belonged to the side of America.
This license was structured under the "foreign jurisdiction method" where the management rights belonged to the side of America.
This license was structured under the "foreign jurisdiction method" where the management rights belonged to the side of America.

sen.j: 明治になってからアメリカ側はこの免許を根拠に建設要請を行ったが、明治政府は「この書面の幕府側の署名は、京都の新政府発足後のもので外交的権限を有しないもの」である旨をもって却下している。
sen.e: At the start of the Meiji Period, America requested the construction be based on the license, however the Meiji Government declined the request on the grounds that the license was signed by Bakufu after the new government in Kyoto went into effect and it lacked a diplomatic authority.

At the start of the Meiji Period, America requested the construction based on the license, but the Meiji Government declined the request on the grounds that the license was signed by Bakufu after the new government in Kyoto went into effect and it lacked a diplomatic authority.

At the start of the Meiji Period, America requested the construction based on the license, but the Meiji Government declined the request on the grounds that the license was signed by Bakufu after the new government in Kyoto went into effect and it lacked a diplomatic authority.

sen.j: その後新政府内部で鉄道建設について検討が行われ、明治2年（1869年）11月に自国管轄方式によって新橋・横浜間の鉄道建設を決めた。
sen.e: Subsequently the railroad construction was debated within the new government and in November 1869, and it was decided to construct the railroad between Shinbashi and Yokohama under its own control and management method.

Subsequently the railroad construction was debated within the new government and in November 1869, and it was decided to construct the railroad between Shinbashi and Yokohama under its own control and management method.

Subsequently the railroad construction was debated within the new government and in November 1869, and it was decided to construct the railroad between Shinbashi and Yokohama under its own control and management method.

sen.j: 当時の日本では自力での建設は無理なので、技術や資金を援助する国としてイギリスを選定した。
sen.e: It was impossible for Japan to handle construction on its own, so they looked towards England to provide technical and financial assistance.
It was impossible for Japan to handle construction on its own, so they chose England to obtain technical and financial assistance.
sen.cmt: 選定した。.→choseto provide technical and financial assistance.→to obtain technical and financial assistance
sen.e: It was impossible for Japan to handle construction on its own, so they chose England to obtain technical and financial assistance.

sen.j: これは鉄道発祥国イギリスの技術力を評価したことと、日本の鉄道について建設的な提言を行っていた駐日公使ハリー・パークスの存在も大きかった。
sen.e: England was selected after being recognized for its technology as the country of origin of the railroads, and also the constructive advice given by the British Minister to Japan Harry Burks played a significant role.

England was selected after being recognized for its technology as the country of origin of the railroads, and because the British Minister to Japan, Harry Burks gave a positive advice on Japanese railway.
sen.cmt: 意味が違うので、後半を訂正します。
sen.e: England was selected after being recognized for its technology as the country of origin of the railroads, and because the British Minister to Japan, Harry Burks gave a positive advice on Japanese railway.

sen.j: 翌明治3年1870年イギリスからエドモンド・モレルが建築師長に着任して本格的工事が始まった。
sen.e: The following year in 1870, Edmond Morell of England was appointed as chief architect and the construction started in earnest.
In the following year in 1870, Edmond Morell from England was appointed as chief architect and construction started.
sen.cmt: of.→fromInを追加、原文にないのでimmediately after削除。
sen.e: In the following year in 1870, Edmond Morell from England was appointed as chief architect and construction started.

sen.j: 日本側では明治4年（1871年）に井上勝（日本の鉄道の父）が鉱山頭兼鉄道頭に就任して建設に携わった。
sen.e: In 1871, Masaru INOUE (Father of Japan's railroad) joined the project from the Japan side by taking up the position of the bureau head for Mine and Railroad.
In 1871, Masaru INOUE (Father of Japan's railroad) joined the project from the Japan side by taking up the position of Mine and Railroad head.
sen.cmt: 定冠詞を追加します。鉱山頭兼鉄道頭はMine and Railroad headかどうか未確認です。
sen.e: In 1871, Masaru INOUE (Father of Japan's railroad) joined the project from the Japan side by taking up the position of Mine and Railroad head.

sen.j: 日本の鉄道は明治5年（1872年）9月12日 (旧暦)（旧暦、新暦だと10月14日）に、新橋駅・横浜駅間で正式開業した。
sen.e: Japan Railways was formally opened on September 12 (old calendar), (October 14 by new calendar) in the 5th year of the Meiji Era (1872) between Shinbashi station and Yokohama station.
Japanese railway was formally opened on September 12, 1872 between Shinbashi Station and Yokohama Station.
Japanese railway was formally opened on September 12, 1872 between Shinbashi Station and Yokohama Station.

sen.j: ただし、実際にはその数ヶ月前から品川駅・横浜駅間で仮営業が行われていた。
sen.e: However, it was actually operated between Shinagawa station and Yokohama station for test runs a few months prior to the formal opening day.
However, it was actually operated between Shinagawa Station and Yokohama Station for test runs a few months prior to the formal opening day.
However, it was actually operated between Shinagawa Station and Yokohama Station for test runs a few months prior to the formal opening day.

sen.j: 鉄道は大評判となり、開業翌年には大幅な利益を計上したが、運賃収入の大半は旅客収入であった。
sen.e: It was a big success and following the opening year, it made a big profit and most of the revenue was from the passengers fares.
It was a big success and in the year following the opening year, it made a big profit and most of the revenue was from the passengers fares.
It was a big success and in the year following the opening year, it made a big profit and most of the revenue was from the passengers fares.

sen.j: 以上詳しくは、日本の鉄道開業を参照。
sen.e: Refer to the opening of Japan railroad for further details.
Refer to the opening of Japanese railways for further details.
Refer to the opening of Japanese railways for further details.

sen.j: 鉄道の輸送力を決定付ける軌間は、国際標準軌（1435mm）より狭い狭軌の1067mmが選ばれた。
sen.e: The track gauge selected for use that affected transportation capacity was the narrow gauge (1067mm) as opposed to the International standard gauge (1435mm).
The track gauge selected for use that affected transportation capacity was the narrow gauge (1067mm) as opposed to the International standard gauge (1435mm).
The track gauge selected for use that affected transportation capacity was the narrow gauge (1067mm) as opposed to the International standard gauge (1435mm).

sen.j: これは当時の日本の状況を考えると妥当な選択であった。
sen.e: It was an appropriate decision considering Japan's circumstances at the time.
It was an appropriate decision considering Japan's circumstances at the time.
It was an appropriate decision considering Japan's circumstances at the time.

sen.j: すなわち軌間が広いほど大きな列車を速く走らせることができるが、建設費がかさむ事が欠点である。
sen.e: Although a wider track guage allowed bigger trains to operate at faster speed, the drawback was that the wider gauge would cost more.
The drawback was that the wider gauge would cost higher construction expense.
sen.cmt: 「建設費がかさむ事」訂正します。訳漏れ「すなわち軌間が広いほど大きな列車を速く走らせることができるが、」
sen.e: Although a wider track guage allowed bigger trains to operate at faster speed, the drawback was that the wider gauge would cost higher construction expense.

sen.j: 特に軌間が大きいほどカーブを大きく取る必要があり、貧乏国で山がちの日本では標準軌は贅沢であった。
sen.e: Especially considering how the wider gauge required a wider curb and more space, the standard gauge was not affordable nor practical to the mountainous and financially poor Japan.
Especially considering the wider gauge required a wider curb and more space, the standard gauge was not affordable nor practical to the mountainous and financially poor Japan.
Especially considering the wider gauge required a wider curb and more space, the standard gauge was not affordable nor practical to the mountainous and financially poor Japan.

sen.j: 当時のイギリス植民地であった南アフリカやニュージーランドも1067mmを採用している。
sen.e: The British colonies of South Africa and New Zealand adopted the 1067mm gauge.
The British colonies of South Africa and New Zealand adopted the 1067mm gauge.
The British colonies of South Africa and New Zealand adopted the 1067mm gauge.

sen.j: その他の技術的ポイントを列記する。
sen.e: Other technical points are listed.
Other technical points are listed.
Other technical points are listed.

sen.j: 実際の建設に際しては、土木工事は築城経験のある日本の技術が生かされたが、現在の多摩川にかかる六郷川橋梁だけはイギリス人の指導の下に木造で架橋された（明治10年に鉄橋に交換）。
sen.e: For actual construction, technology for castle construction was utilized, although only wooden bridge; Rogougawakyoryo over present-day Tamagawa River was built under the supervision of an Englishman (which was replaced with an iron bridge in the 10th year of the Meiji Era).

For actual construction, technology for castle construction was utilized, although only a wooden bridge over the present-day Tamagawa River was built under the supervision of an Englishman (which was replaced with an iron bridge in the 10th year of the Meiji Era).

For actual construction, technology for castle construction was utilized, although only a wooden bridge over the present-day Tamagawa River was built under the supervision of an Englishman (which was replaced with an iron bridge in the 10th year of the Meiji Era).

sen.j: 車輌は全てイギリスから輸入された。
sen.e: All trains were imported from England.
All the trains were imported from England.
All the trains were imported from England.

sen.j: 蒸気機関車10両は全て軸配置1Bのタンク機関車で5社の製品を混合使用した。
sen.e: All ten steam locomotives were tank locomotives with 1B axle arrangement comprised of the mixed products use from the five companies.
All the ten steam locomotives were tank locomotives with 1B axle arrangement.
sen.cmt: 定冠詞を追加します。「5社の製品を混合使用した。」訳漏れです。
sen.e: All ten steam locomotives were tank locomotives with 1B axle arrangement comprised of the mixed products use from the five companies.

sen.j: その中で4両あったシャープ・スチュアート社製の機関車が最も使いやすかったと言われている。
sen.e: Four of them were made by Sharp Stewart Co., Ltd. and were said to be easiest for operation.
Four of them were made by Sharp Stewart Co., Ltd. and were said to be easiest for operation.
Four of them were made by Sharp Stewart Co., Ltd. and were said to be easiest for operation.

sen.j: 客車は全て2軸で上等車（定員18人）10両、中等車（定員26人）40両、緩急車8両が輸入されたが、開業前に中等車26両は定員52人の下等車に改造された。
sen.e: Although all trains had two axels and consisted of 10 upper class trains (18 seats), 40 middle class trains (26 seats) and 8 cabooses (train with hand-on brake), just before the opening, 26 middle class trains were converted to the lower class trains with the seating capacity for 52 passengers.

sen.e: Because of Tokaido Road's flourishing maritime transportation and expensive train fares, it wasn't expected much ridership, and furthermore there was a strong objection from the Army that Tokaido Road's proximity to the coastal line left it vulnerable to foreign attack.

Because of Tokaido Road's flourishing maritime transportation and high railway fees, along with strong objections from the Army that Tokaido Road's proximity to the coastal line left it vulnerable to foreign attack, the railway was not expected to be any competition.

sen.e: The total service distance of the government-owned railway before the buyout was 2,459km and the total service line distance after the buyout was 4.806km.

sen.j: 買収の可否判断に際しては、国内輸送の基幹となる路線を優先することになった。
sen.e: The buyout decision was made based on priority given to the line that could become a part of the main artery line.
The buyout decision was made based on priority given to the line that could become a part of the main artery line.
The buyout decision was made based on priority given to the line that could become a part of the main artery line.

sen.j: 当時、南海電気鉄道は難波駅 - 和歌山市駅間、東武鉄道は北千住駅 - 久喜駅間の営業を行っていたが、和歌山方面には買収対象である関西鉄道の路線、関東北部へは同じく日本鉄道の路線があったため、国有化の対象に一時は含まれたことがあったものの、最終的には予算問題もあって外された。
sen.e: Nankai Railway operated between Namba Station and Wakayama City Station, and Tobu Railway operated Kitasenju Station and Kuki Station, and both were considered for the buyout candidates at one time, however there was Kansai Railway in Wakayama district and the lines operated by Nippon Railway in Northern Kanto district which were both the buyout candidates, but were excluded from the buyout in the end due to budgetary constraints.

Nankai Railway operated between Namba Station and Wakayama City Station, and Tobu Railway operated between Kitasenju Station and Kuki Station, and both were considered for the buyout at one time, but as there were Kansai Railway in Wakayama district and the lines operated by Nippon Railway in Northern Kanto district which were both the buyout candidates, they were excluded from the buyout due to budgetary constraints.
sen.cmt: Nanbaの誤記、between追加.was→were訳者が2文で翻訳しているので、1文に訂正。
sen.e: Nankai Railway operated between Namba Station and Wakayama City Station, and Tobu Railway operated between Kitasenju Station and Kuki Station, and both were considered for the buyout at one time, but as there were Kansai Railway in Wakayama district and the lines operated by Nippon Railway in Northern Kanto district which were both the buyout candidates, they were excluded from the buyout due to budgetary constraints.

sen.j: 買収の結果「国有鉄道」となったので以後国鉄と表記する。
sen.e: After the buyout, all became the nationally owned railway thus called Kokutetsu thereafter.
After the buyout, all which became the "nationally owned railway" thus called Japan National Railways thereafter.
sen.cmt: 関係代名詞を挿入,Kokutetsuを訂正。""追加。
sen.e: After the buyout, all which became the "nationally owned railway" thus called Japan National Railways thereafter.

sen.j: 最初の効果は長距離列車の設定であり、東京・下関間の直通列車や、奥羽線経由の上野・青森間直通列車などが設定された。
sen.e: The first benefit of nationalization was establishing a long distance service like a direct train service between Tokyo and Shimonoseki, and a direct train service between Ueno and Aomori via Ohu Honsen.

The first benefit of nationalization was establishing a long distance service like a direct train service between Tokyo and Shimonoseki, and a direct train service between Ueno and Aomori via Ohu Main Line.

The first benefit of nationalization was establishing a long distance service like a direct train service between Tokyo and Shimonoseki, and a direct train service between Ueno and Aomori via Ohu Main Line.

sen.j: また車輌を全国的に運用して各地方の繁忙・閑散に応じた配置が可能になった。
sen.e: Also, the utilization of railway vehicles were maximized in keeping up with the demand of the local seasonal change.
Also, the utilization of railway vehicles were maximized in keeping up with the demand of the local seasonal change.
Also, the utilization of railway vehicles were maximized in keeping up with the demand of the local seasonal change.

sen.j: その反面、国鉄の保有する車輌は蒸気機関車だけでも174形式1118両、客車3067両、貨車20884両におよび、運用・整備・修理に大きな困難が発生した。
sen.e: On the other hand, it amassed a huge fleet of trains with 1,118 Model 174 locomotives, 3,067 passenger trains, 20,884 cargo trains and consequently faced an enormous difficulty for operation, maintenance, and repair.

On the other hand, it amassed a huge fleet of trains with 1,118 Model 174 locomotives, 3,067 passenger trains, 20,884 cargo trains and consequently faced an enormous difficulty for operation, maintenance, and repair.

On the other hand, it amassed a huge fleet of trains with 1,118 Model 174 locomotives, 3,067 passenger trains, 20,884 cargo trains and consequently faced an enormous difficulty for operation, maintenance, and repair.

sen.j: この後国鉄は車輌・機材の国産化と標準化を進める。
sen.e: Afterwards, Kokutetsu went ahead to push for the standardization and domestic production of trains and equipment.
Afterwards, Japan National Railways went ahead with the standardization and domestic production of trains and equipment.
sen.cmt: Kokutetsuを訂正。進める→went ahead with
sen.e: Afterwards, Japan National Railways went ahead with the standardization and domestic production of trains and equipment.

sen.j: 最初の鉄道は、車輌もレールも鉄橋も外国製で、トンネル掘削はお雇い外人が指導し、機関車の運転もダイヤの作成もお雇い外国人が行った。
sen.e: The first railroad was comprised of all foreign-made trains, track rails and iron bridges while the tunnel digging, locomotive operation, and making of the timetables were handled by hired foreign engineers.

The first railroad was comprised of all foreign-made trains, track rails, and iron bridges while the tunnel digging, locomotive operation, and making of the timetables were conducted by foreign engineers.
sen.cmt: 訳抜けの「鉄橋も」追加, handled→conducted
sen.e: The first railroad was comprised of all foreign-made trains, track rails, and iron bridges while the tunnel digging, locomotive operation, and making of the timetables were conducted by foreign engineers.

sen.j: 日本人は外国に学びながら徐々に技術力を蓄え、順次国産化していった。
sen.e: Japanese gradually gained technological skills as they learned from foreign countries and proceeded toward their domestic production in steps.
Japanese gradually gained technological skills as they learned from foreign countries.
Japanese gradually gained technological skills as they learned from foreign countries and proceeded toward their domestic production in steps.

sen.j: トンネルでは、1880年に完成した東海道線の京都と大津間の逢坂山トンネル（664.8m）が、お雇い外人に頼らずに掘削された。
sen.e: For tunnel construction, in 1889 Japanese dug Osakayama tunnel between Kyoto and Otsu (664.8m) on the Tokaido Line without the help of foreigners.
For tunnel construction, in 1880 the Japanese dug Osakayama tunnel between Kyoto and Otsu (664.8m) without the help of foreigners.
sen.cmt: 定冠詞を追加します。訳抜けを挿入。年号の誤りを訂正。
sen.e: For tunnel construction, in 1880 the Japanese dug Osakayama tunnel between Kyoto and Otsu (664.8m) without the help of foreigners.

sen.j: 日本人機関士第1号は1879年。
sen.e: In 1879, the first Japanese engineer was born.
In 1879, the first Japanese engineer was born.
In 1879, the first Japanese engineer was born.

sen.j: レールの国産化は1907年。
sen.e: The domestic production of rail was achieved in 1907.
The domestic production of rail was achieved in 1907.
The domestic production of rail was achieved in 1907.

sen.j: 車輌は、木造客車や貨車の改造は木工技術があったので開通当初から実行していたが、蒸気機関車の製作は近代技術の習得に応じて進んでいった。
sen.e: While the modifications of wooden passenger and cargo trains were done by Japanese craftsmen with woodworking skills from the start of the opening however, steam engine production made progress as they learned and gained the skills of modern technology.
While train modifications were left to Japanese craftsmen with woodworking skills, steam engine production held a steady pace as they grasped the technology.
sen.cmt: 数ヶ所の訳漏れあります。
sen.e: While the modifications of wooden passenger and cargo trains were done by Japanese craftsmen with woodworking skills from the start of the opening however, steam engine production made progress as they learned and gained the skills of modern technology.

sen.j: 1893年、お雇い外国人トレビシックの設計・指導の下に官営鉄道神戸工場で軸配置1B1タンク機の国鉄860形蒸気機関車が完成。
sen.e: In 1893, the domestically manufactured model JNR 860 steam locomotive with an axel arrangement 1B1tank machine was completed with a design and supervision by hired foreigner Trevithick in Japan.
In 1893, the domestically manufactured model 860 steam locomotive with an axis arrangement 1B1 tank machine was completed with a design and supervision by hired foreigners in Japan.
In 1893, the domestically manufactured model 860 steam locomotive with an axis arrangement 1B1 tank machine was completed with a design and supervision by hired foreigners in Japan.

sen.j: 国産といっても主要部品は輸入品であった。
sen.e: It was domestically produced however its major parts were imported.
It was domestically produced, but its major parts were imported.
It was domestically produced, but its major parts were imported.

sen.j: 1903年、井上勝が中心となって設立した汽車製造で軸配置1B1タンク機の国鉄230形蒸気機関車が完成。
sen.e: In 1903, the Kokutetsu model 230 steam locomotive with an axel arrangement 1B1 tank machine was completed at Kisha Seizo which was founded by Masaru INIOUE and his colleagues.
In 1903, the Japan National Railways model 230 steam locomotive with an axis arrangement 1B1 tank machine was completed at Kisha Seizo founded by Masaru INOUE and his group.
sen.cmt: 国鉄→Japan National Railways, axel→axis,「井上勝が中心となって設立した汽車製造」の誤訳訂正
sen.e: In 1903, the Japan National Railways model 230 steam locomotive with an axis arrangement 1B1 tank machine was completed at Kisha Seizo founded by Masaru INOUE and his group.

sen.j: 1911年、軸配置2Bテンダ機の国鉄6700形蒸気機関車が製造される。
sen.e: In 1911, Kokutetsu model 6700 with an axis arrangement 2B Tenda machine was produced.
In 1911, Japan National Railways model 6700 with an axis arrangement 2B Tenda machine was produced.
sen.cmt: 国鉄→Japan National Railways, axel→axis,Tenda machine正しい訳か不明。
sen.e: In 1911, Japan National Railways model 6700 with an axis arrangement 2B Tenda machine was produced.

sen.j: このタイプは日本人の設計による純国産機で、汽車会社と川崎造船所で合計46両生産された。
sen.e: This type was purely a domestic product designed by Japanese and 46 of them all were manufactured at Kisha Kaisha and Kawasaki Zosen shipyard.
This type was purely a domestic product designed by Japanese and 46 of them in total were manufactured at Kisha Kaisha and Kawasaki Zosen shipyard.
This type was purely a domestic product designed by Japanese and 46 of them in total were manufactured at Kisha Kaisha and Kawasaki Zosen shipyard.

sen.j: 主要部品のボイラーや煙管なども国産品であった。
sen.e: All major parts as well as funnels were all domestically produced.
All major parts as well as funnels were all domestically produced.
All major parts as well as funnels were all domestically produced.

sen.j: 1911年に本格的輸入機の最後となる大型の急行用機関車60両を輸入した。
sen.e: In 1911, the last of major imports for 60 locomotives for large express trains were imported.
In 1911, 60 locomotives for large express trains, which were the last imported locomotives, were imported.
sen.cmt: 「本格的輸入機の最後となる大型の急行用機関車」の誤訳訂正
sen.e: In 1911, 60 locomotives for large express trains, which were the last imported locomotives, were imported.

sen.j: 2Cテンダ国鉄8700形蒸気機関車12両（イギリス）、2Cテンダ国鉄8800形蒸気機関車12両と国鉄8850形蒸気機関車12両（ドイツ）、2C1テンダ国鉄8900形蒸気機関車24両（アメリカ）の4形式の蒸気機関車である。
sen.e: The 4 models of imported steam locomotives consisted of 12 2C Tenda Kokutetsu model 8700 steam locomotives (England), 12 2C Tenda Kokutetsu model 880 steam locomotives and 12 Kokutetsu model 8900 steam locomotives (Germany), 24 2C1 Tenda Kokutetsu model 8900's (USA).

The 4 models of imported steam locomotives consisted of 12 2C Tenda Japan National Railways model 8700 steam locomotives (England), 12 2C Tenda Japan National Railways model 880 steam locomotives and 12 Japan National Railways model 8900 steam locomotives (Germany), 24 2C1 Tenda Japan National Railways model 8900 steam locomotives (USA).

The 4 models of imported steam locomotives consisted of 12 2C Tenda Japan National Railways model 8700 steam locomotives (England), 12 2C Tenda Japan National Railways model 880 steam locomotives and 12 Japan National Railways model 8900 steam locomotives (Germany), 24 2C1 Tenda Japan National Railways model 8900 steam locomotives (USA).

sen.j: 8700形以外は当時の最新技術である過熱蒸気を採用していたが、いずれも東海道線や山陽線の旅客列車を牽引した。
sen.e: With the exception of the 8700, all models used superheated steam which was the latest technology at the time and were placed in service to pull passenger trains on the Tokaido Line and Sanyo Line.
With the exception of the 8700, all models used superheated steam which was the latest technology at the time and were placed in service to pull passenger trains on the Tokaido Line and Sanyo Line.
